Template.Support: Trip manager / 1st response medic | Support vehicle | Consulting doctor

FullDescription.p: Please be aware that you are responsible for all damage caused to the motorcycle, and on these bigger adventure bikes, these costs can add up very quickly.
See â€˜Optional Extrasâ€™ below for â€˜Motorcycle Damage Insuranceâ€™.

Youâ€™ll need to book flights to arrive in Temuco AraucanÃ­a Airport, Chile (airport code: ZCO) on or before the morning of Day 1 of this trip. You will then fly out of Presidente Carlos IbÃ¡Ã±ez del Campo International Airport, Chile (PUQ) on the last day of the trip.
While other locations will connect with these two airports, Santiago, Chile (SCL) will be the easiest major international airport for most visitors to fly via.
It is important you either:

ul.li: Book a flexible flight ticket that allows you to make amendments or cancel without penalty;
Have travel insurance that you will reimburse you for out of pocket expenses incurred by a cancelled trip;
Do not book your flights until we have notified you that this departure is guaranteed.
Alcohol;
Laundry;
Souvenirs;
Any meals that are not mentioned in the itinerary;
Recovery, oil, spare parts, labour or other indirect costs resulting from the damage or repair of your motorcycle;
Emergency transportation;
Any other item, optional excursion, activity or entrance fee that is not specifically mentioned as being included.

FullDescription.p: Road / adventure style kit is the way to go on this motorcycle tour, rather than off-road or enduro gear. So that means a good helmet, protective riding jacket and trousers, ideally with CE or equivalent approved armour on the pointy bits â€“ elbows, knees and shoulders.
You are also going to need good leather gloves, a neck tube, thermal base layers and a sturdy pair of motorcycle boots.
Please bring waterproofs if your kit doesnâ€™t keep out the wet stuff.
It is a condition of booking that you obtain appropriate travel insurance that covers you for riding the same capacity motorcycle that youâ€™ll be riding on this motorcycle tour.
The insurance must cover emergency evacuation, medical bills, repatriation etc.

Cost.BriefDescription: What payment methods do you accept?

FullDescription.p: We accept GBP payments by Visa, Mastercard & American Express and direct bank transfers. Please get in touch if you would rather pay in another currency - we'll do our best to accommodate!
If you cancel your booking before departure, cancellation charges will be applied as follows:

ul.li: 61 days or more before tour start date â€“ retention of deposit
42-60 days before tour start date â€“ retention of 50% of tour price
28-41 days before tour start date â€“ retention of 70% of tour price
0-27 days before tour start date â€“ retention of 100% tour price

FullDescription.p: Please refer to our Terms & Conditions for further info regarding cancellations, changes and transferring your trip to a friend.

Cost.BriefDescription: What is the official travel advice?

FullDescription.p: For the most accurate and up to date info on travel advice for Patagonia, we advise you to visit the foreign office website.

Follow this link for Chile travel advice, and this link for Argentina advice from the UK foreign office. As we are a UK company, this is the official government advice we follow. If you are not a UK resident, we advise you search for the equivalent info from your own countryâ€™s foreign office, as travel advice may differ.

Cost.BriefDescription: Can you cater for food allergies / vegetarians / vegans on this trip?

FullDescription.p: This really should not be a problem in Patagonia and we will make every effort possible to communicate your requirements to the places we visit. However, as we are not preparing the meals ourselves, we are unable to make cast iron guarantees. If you are going to go into a life-threatening spasm if you touch a stray peanut, then please let us know â€“ we need to know that stuff, we really do.

Cost.BriefDescription: What are the health / immunisation considerations?

FullDescription.p: For the most accurate and up to date info, we advise you visit the â€˜Travel Health Proâ€™ website. Follow this link for Chile info and this link for Argentina info.
Please also consult with your own doctor at home at least 8 weeks before your trip.
In Chile, the local currency is the Chilean peso (symbol: $, code: CLP). USD is not widely accepted in Chile.
In Argentina, the local currency is the Argentine peso (symbol: $, code: ARS). USD is widely accepted in Argentina.

Cost.BriefDescription: Which plug types are used in Patagonia?

FullDescription.p: We recommend you bring a Type C adaptor as this will work in both Chile & Argentina.

For Chile there are two associated plug types, types C and L. Plug type C is the plug which has two round pins and type L is the plug which has three round pins in a horizontal line. Chile operates on a 220V supply voltage and 50Hz.

For Argentina there are two associated plug types, types C and I. Plug type C is the plug which has two round pins and plug type I is the plug which has three flat pins in a triangular pattern. Argentina operates on a 220V supply voltage and 50Hz.

Cost.BriefDescription: Can I get a local sim card?

FullDescription.p: Yes, please do ðŸ¤ <./p>

At the time of writing, British nationals do not need a visa to enter Argentina or Chile as a tourist for periods of 90 days or less. However, we always recommend you check the foreign office website for the most accurate and up to date information relating to visas and other entry requirements.

Follow this link for Chile entry requirements and this link for Argentina entry requirements. These links to the UK foreign office website â€“ if you are not a UK resident, please search for the equivalent info from your home countryâ€™s foreign office.
Yes, there are ATMs in the larger towns, but not the villages.

Donâ€™t forget to tell your bank you are heading to Chile and Argentina, as without this information they will most likely think some rogue hacker is dipping into your account and promptly block your card.

Cost.BriefDescription: What documents / licenses do I need?

FullDescription.p: To be legally riding in Argentina and Chile you are required to carry your local driving licence, which must cover the size of bike you will be riding. This will also be a stipulation of any travel insurance company too.
You will also need an International Driving Permit (IDP). An IDP is basically an official, multi-language translation of your driving licence.
You will also need some paperwork to cross borders with your motorcycle, but we take care of all of this for you.

This tour is a mix of tarmac and gravel roads, so you will need to be competent and confident riding a similar size motorcycle on the gravel. While the majority of the gravel roads are well maintained, there will inevitably be sections of deeper gravel in places.
Please also be aware that we will encounter some seriously strong winds on this tour.
If you are unsure of your experience, please let us know and we will talk you through. We may also recommend you take an off-road adventure rider training course prior to signing up to the trip.

Cost.BriefDescription: How much spending money will I need?

FullDescription.p: As this is a largely inclusive tour, you wonâ€™t need much. You will only need money for the items not listed as inclusions, which is mainly just alcohol, souvenirs, some evening meals and any other personal spending. Unless you go mad in the gift shops and bars, around Â£300 â€“ Â£400 should be adequate. Shopping in Chile and Argentina tends to be very reasonable so you can get quite a lot for not much!

Cost.BriefDescription: What will the weather be like?

FullDescription.p: Patagonia â€“ â€˜The End of the Worldâ€™ â€“ is known for its harsh conditions. While we schedule our motorcycle tours during the optimum riding months, you can still expect extreme conditions! Temperatures will range from 2Â°C â€“ 25Â°C, we will probably get caught in some rain and we WILL get hit with some seriously strong winds.

Cost.BriefDescription: Is wi-fi available throughout the trip?

FullDescription.p: Most of the accommodations (but not all) will have wi-fi, but there will be a few places where the wi-fi is quite slow.
To secure your place we simply need a Â£500 non-refundable deposit. The remainder does not need to be paid until 60 days prior to the tour start date.

Yes. All passengers booking with Ride Expeditions Ltd are fully insured for the initial deposit, and subsequently the balance of monies paid as detailed in your booking confirmation form. The policy also includes repatriation if required, arising from the cancellation or curtailment of your travel arrangements due to the insolvency of Ride Expeditions Ltd. This insurance has been arranged by Towergate Travel through Zurich Insurance PLC.

Yes. Here at Ride Expeditions, we take the necessary precautions to ensure that we protect both ourselves and you as the customer, with insurances covering financial failure, public liability, professional indemnity and employers liability (you will need your own travel insurance).

To obtain this insurance we must meet strict safety standards and local regulations. We must also carry out thorough risk assessments about all aspects of a tour before tyres can hit tarmac (â€¦or dirt!).

Cost.BriefDescription: What's the minimum number of riders required for this tour?

FullDescription.p: The minimum required number for this trip to run is 6 riders. We reserve the right to cancel the tour if this number is not met and we will provide you with a minimum of 56 days notice. Please know that this is an absolute last resort for us and we will always do everything in our power to avoid this happening.

Cost.BriefDescription: Is this trip suitable for those with limited mobility?

FullDescription.p: Not riding the motorcycle, no (although this will of course depend on the extent of your limited mobility). However, we may be able to accommodate you in our support vehicle. We advise you to give us a call and we can discuss.

Cost.BriefDescription: What is the average group size?

FullDescription.p: Average group sizes are 8-9 riders and we limit the groups to 12 riders.
Ride to the 'Worldâ€™s End' - the southernmost city in the world.
Experience Tierra del Fuego, the Land of Fire: the ultimate adventure riding destination!
See Patagonian gauchos astride their beautiful criollo horses up close and personal.
Stay in luxury resorts, rustic lodges, Patagonian haciendas and farmhouse-style hotels.
Sample local cuisine and the world-famous Chilean wine and Argentinian asado (traditional South American BBQ).
Experience the true meaning of adventure riding both on and off road in the Patagonian wilderness.
Ride winding gravel roads across the mountains between Chile and Argentina.
Enjoy the awe-inspiring snow-capped mountains & stunning scenery of the Torres del Paine National Park.
Twin-share accommodation is included as standard â€“ see â€˜Optional Extrasâ€™ below for single room availability and pricing.
Please see the daily itinerary for details on the type of accommodation.
On this tour we stay in excellent 4-5* hotels & resorts where available, and the very best available accommodation where options are more limited.

Youâ€™ll be collected from Temuco AraucanÃ­a Airport (airport code: ZCO) on the morning of the first day. It is important you book the early morning (approx 07h30) flight from Santiago (SCL) as we will be collecting the group together in a small coach / minivan and driving 1h30 to our hotel in Pucon. (You are of course welcome to arrive a day or two earlier, but there will be an extra cost for airport pickup).
At the end of the trip we will arrange transfers from our final hotel to Presidente Carlos IbÃ¡Ã±ez del Campo International Airport (PUQ).
We will prepare all required paperwork for crossing borders with your motorcycle.

ul.li: Ferry crossings;
Torres del Paine National Park;
Tierra del Fuego National Park;
Shuttle and boat trip to visit Perito Moreno glacier.

FullDescription.p: INCLUDED IN THE â€˜RIDER PRICEâ€™
The BMW F700 GS is included as standard (these will be replaced by the F750 GS in November 2022). See â€˜Optional Extrasâ€™ below for upgrade options and damage waiver insurance.
INCLUDED:

ul.li: Panniers;
Shipping of the motorcycle from Punta Arenas back to the start point;
Third party insurance in both Argentina and Chile.

FullDescription.p: We organise your motorcycle rental with our preferred rental provider in Chile. Your contract for the motorcycle rental is direct with the provider and youâ€™ll be required to sign their contract when receiving your motorcycle in Chile. You must comply with the terms & conditions of the rental provider. Upon request, we can provide you with a copy of these terms & conditions in advance.

This motorcycle tour of Patagonia is accompanied by a large support vehicle, equipped to carry your luggage, an extensive medical kit + stretcher + AED, drinking water, snacks, tools and spare parts. It is also capable of carrying a motorcycle & passengers in the event of a breakdown / emergency.
Your tour will be led and managed by a bilingual member of the Ride Expeditions team, highly experienced in leading expeditions in South America.

Ride Expeditions Ltd is committed to customer satisfaction and consumer financial protection. At no extra cost to you, and in accordance with â€˜The Package Travel and Linked Travel Arrangements Regulations 2018â€™, all passengers booking with Ride Expeditions Ltd are fully insured for the initial deposit, and subsequently the balance of monies paid as detailed in your booking confirmation form.

The policy also includes repatriation if required, arising from the cancellation or curtailment of your travel arrangements due to the insolvency of Ride Expeditions Ltd. This insurance has been arranged by Towergate Travel through Zurich Insurance PLC.
During the COVID-19 crisis, every rider that requested a refund was issued a cash refund.

This motorcycle tour is accompanied by a GPS tracker that displays our live location and track history on an online map. We will provide you with the link and login details which you can then share with your family at home so they can track your progress throughout the trip.
At least one member of the support team will have been trained as a Wilderness First Response medic.
An extensive medical kit including a defibrillator (AED) & stretcher is carried in the support vehicle.

We also have consulting doctors on call, 24/7, who are always ready to assist in the case of an emergency. Our doctors are fully briefed on all riders medical info prior to the tour, they know what we do, where we are riding, exactly what we have in our medical kit and what training our medics have.
Tours are accompanied by GPS trackers and a satellite messenger device so our doctor and office can see exactly where we are and can maintain communication.
In an effort to off-set our carbon emissions, we also plant a tree for every rider that books with us, by donating to One Tree Planted.
Since the day Ride Expeditions started running tours in Cambodia back in 2012, we have been dedicated to supporting the local community.
Part profits from every motorcycle tour are donated to Mâ€™Lop Tapang â€“ a local Cambodian charity dedicated to bettering the lives of young children & their families.
Weâ€™ll welcome you with a bag of Ride Expeditions goodies which will include:

ul.li: T-shirt;
Baseball cap;
Map;
Stickers;
Mug;
Keyring;
Neck tube.

FullDescription.p: Breakfast, lunch and dinner is provided on most days.
Please see the daily itinerary to see what meals are included on each day.
All fuel for your motorcycle is provided by us and we carry spare fuel in our support vehicle for the sections of the route where fuel stations are scarce.
Single room accommodation is available for 14 of the 17 nights. Sharing rooms is the only option in Lago Posadas and Estancia.

Cost.BriefDescription: Upgrade to BMW F800 GS + Â£160

FullDescription.p: BMW F800 GS (these will be replaced by the F850 GS in November 2022).
INCLUDED:

ul.li: Panniers;
Shipping of the motorcycle from Punta Arenas back to the start point;
Third party insurance in both Argentina and Chile.

FullDescription.p: We organise your motorcycle rental with our preferred rental provider in Chile. Your contract for the motorcycle rental is direct with the provider and youâ€™ll be required to sign their contract when receiving your motorcycle in Chile. You must comply with the terms & conditions of the rental provider. Upon request, we can provide you with a copy of these terms & conditions in advance.

Cost.BriefDescription: Upgrade to BMW R1250 GS + Â£700

FullDescription.p: BMW R1250 GS (these will be replaced by the F850 GS in November 2022).
INCLUDED:

ul.li: Panniers;
Shipping of the motorcycle from Punta Arenas back to the start point;
Third party insurance in both Argentina and Chile.

FullDescription.p: We organise your motorcycle rental with our preferred rental provider in Chile. Your contract for the motorcycle rental is direct with the provider and youâ€™ll be required to sign their contract when receiving your motorcycle in Chile. You must comply with the terms & conditions of the rental provider. Upon request, we can provide you with a copy of these terms & conditions in advance.
This option limits your maximum damage liability to $2,500.

Cost.FullDescription:
Motorcycling in Patagonia is adventure in its purest form: forget busy highways with convenient fuel stations and roadside cafes, bustling cities and fast WiFi. Out here, it feels as though youâ€™re traveling in the outback, so remote and so untouched by civilisation you will almost feel like youâ€™re the first human on Earth.
This motorcycle tour of Patagonia is an all-encompassing route, designed as a truly â€˜once in a lifetimeâ€™ adventure that ticks all the boxes, leaving no stone unturned and sending you home with a feeling of accomplishment, knowing that youâ€™ve just ridden one of the Worldâ€™s greatest motorcycle adventures.
Weâ€™ll travel some of Patagoniaâ€™s most scenic routes including the famous Ruta 40 and Carreterra Austral, stay in traditional haciendas, experience the gaucho culture and reach Ushuaia, AKA â€œThe Worldâ€™s Endâ€. Ushuaia is the southernmost city of the planet which has long been the absolute pinnacle of adventure motorcycling destinations.
Along the way, weâ€™ll zig and zag between Chile and Argentina traversing the otherworldly Patagonian landscape, cross Torres del Paine National Park, see the natural marble caves, the Perito Moreno glacier and taste the famous Argentinian steak.
Expect the unexpected, prepare for some gravel roads and strong winds, and let the adventure begin!

Cost.BriefDescription: Arrive in Pucon - Bienvenidos a Chile!

FullDescription.p: â€œBienvenidosâ€ (Welcome) is something youâ€™ll hear a lot in Chile and Argentina, as South American hospitality is truly unparalleled.
Youâ€™ll be met at the airport and transferred to Pucon, where your adventure will finally begin!

After a â€˜welcome briefingâ€™ and lunch at the hotel, weâ€™ll jump on the bikes and have a leisurely ride around Lake Caburgua, a Chilean version of Lake Como with jaw-dropping views of the Andean foothills. Thereâ€™s no better way to start your motorcycle tour of Patagonia than getting used to your bike while enjoying the Chilean scenery at a relaxed pace!

Cost.Recommendations: Youâ€™ll need to book a flight to Temuco (airport code: ZCO) from Santiago (airport code: SCL). Please book the early morning (approx 7:30am) flight with Latam Airlines. Flight time is approx 1.5 hours.

FullDescription.p: An excellent dayâ€™s riding is ahead of us as we leave Pucon and venture into the Patagonian backcountry, tackling a mixture of gravel and tarmac roads.

Weâ€™ll skirt around some of Argentinaâ€™s most picturesque lakes, catch a glimpse of Volcano Lanin and hit a region known as the Argentinian Switzerland, with San Carlos de Bariloche as our destination for the day. Bariloche is beloved by locals and travellers alike: famous for its awe-inspiring scenery, bright turquoise lakes corralled by the snow-capped peaks of the Andes and its quirky mountain town vibe, Bariloche is a must-see in Argentina.

Along the way we have our first border crossing, enjoying a traditional style picnic lunch in the countryside, lots of chances to stop for photos, and of course enjoy the phenomenal riding in the Argentinian Patagonia.
Another incredible day of riding today as weâ€™ll join the legendary Ruta 40, Argentinaâ€™s most famous road frequented by two-wheeled travellers from around the world.

Weâ€™ll ride the fantastic Circuito Chico to admire the views of the Lake Perito Moreno, then head South, following the thrilling twisties to Butch Cassidyâ€™s ranch where weâ€™ll stop for lunch and take a tour of the notorious gunslingerâ€™s cabin. Rumour has it, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid held up a bank in Rio Gallegos clearing away over $100,000, but thanks to a tip off from a local Sheriff they managed to escape arrest. True or not, the legend is still alive & well here in rugged Patagonian cowboy country.

Traveling towards Futaleufu (beers are on us if you can pronounce that correctly the first time!), we will experience the insane riding through Los Alerces National Park and end the day back on the Chilean side of the border.
Time to go off grid and brave the wilderness: today, weâ€™ll hit Carreterra Austral, Chileâ€™s most beautiful and remote road meandering across pristine, unspoiled landscape.

Itâ€™s a relaxed day designed to let you catch a breather and take advantage of the breakfast buffet and swimming pool, before we take you for some dirt riding. For the first 50km, weâ€™ll ride a gravel road followed by 90km of tarmac with plenty of curves and bends. Next up is a 40km gravel stretch of vertigo-inducing switchbacks (take it easy on this section!) and then 20kms of paved bliss to finish off the day.

Our hotel has no road access, so when weâ€™re finished with the bikes, weâ€™ll hop on a boat that will take us across the water. If you like natural hot springs, this resort will be right up your street. Thereâ€™s no internet here and itâ€™s a great place to really switch off from the world, have a long soak in the thermal pools, and relax, admiring the shimmering Southern Cross in the unpolluted Chilean skies.

Inching ever closer to some seriously remote Southern lands, weâ€™ll have an early start today heading for Coyhaique, a true frontier town with sculptures and artwork honouring the gaucho culture lining the streets and the best Chilean empanadas in the country.

Weâ€™ll kick the day off riding gravel roads knotted up in narrow switchbacks, then enjoy a 170-kilometre stretch of tarmac leading us through mountains and amazing scenery as we descend into Coyhaique at the end of the day.

If Coyhaique is the capital of Chilean Patagonia, Puerto Rio Tranquilo, is one of its most iconic gaucho towns still retaining the spirit of an authentic, remote outback trading post. Think cowboys, sheriffs, and saloons: founded in the early fifties as a hub for local ranchers, Puerto Rio Tranquilo has stunning natural beauty and a wonderful rugged atmosphere.

Weâ€™ll cover the first 95km of paved roads, then tackle some 120km of gravel with a few sections under construction here and there. Keep an eye out for trucks on the road, but donâ€˜t forget to take in the scenery: today, weâ€™re entering the very heart of Chilean Patagonia.

Along the way, weâ€™ll have a delicious picnic lunch and plenty of photo stops before we arriving in Puerto Rio Tranquilo where we can then relax in a ski chalet-style lodge. Weâ€™ll stay here for two nights for some R&R and the chance to explore the townâ€™s best kept secret: the marble caves!

Puerto Rio Tranquilo translates to â€œThe Port on the Tranquil Riverâ€, so if you feel like putting your feet up and having a relaxed rest day, we canâ€™t blame you: the views, the vibe and the cuisine here are perfect for recharging after some hard days of riding. If, however, youâ€™d like to go on a different type of adventure and explore the marble caves, you can join the three-hour boat excursion to see the surreal caverns on Lake General Carrera.

Still itching to ride? Jump on the bike and ride around the lake, taking in the views of the Andes and chatting to local gauchos youâ€™ll undoubtedly spot here. You can also try your hand at fly fishing or horse riding if you fancy.

Itâ€™s time to leave Chile and return to Argentina, with 165km of gravel, incredible scenery and one of the most exciting stretches of the entire route ahead! Make sure your camera is fully charged: today, youâ€™ll want to stop around every corner for some jaw-dropping photo ops!
On the Argentinian side, weâ€™ll leave the dirt trails behind and hop onto some paved roads leading us to Lago Posadas, a small, windswept Patagonian settlement to finish off the day.

Traveling southward on the fabled Ruta 40 today, weâ€™ll hit the road at 7am to cover some distance (donâ€™t worry about the early star, weâ€™ll arrive at our guesthouse by early afternoon and have the rest of the day off).

Todayâ€™s route is among the loneliest of them all: nothing but the endless Patagonian pampa stretching out as far as the eye can see, the wild guanaco (a creature that resembles the Peruvian llama somewhat) and ostriches our only company on the road.

Brace for the notorious Patagonian side winds today and let your imagination run wild: this is the real deal, the vast, faraway corners of Patagonia, sparsely dotted with a few remote ranches and small settlements here and there.

Brace yourself for a serious adventure today: weâ€™ll tackle 120km of gravel roads leading us through some of Southern Patagoniaâ€™s most scenic landscapes, sprinkled with glacial lagoons and pristine forests. For the first 40km weâ€™ll travel the old Ruta 40 on gravel, then hit the famous 73 Malditos â€“ a stretch of 73km of deep, loose gravel that will require a bit of concentration.

Past Tres Lagos, a town that looks like an old fur trading post, weâ€™ll put in 140km along Lake Viedma, one of the most beautiful glacial lakes in this part of the world. Thereâ€™ll be plenty of challenges, photo stops, and some riding whichâ€™ll feel right out of this world!

Cost.BriefDescription: El Chalten - Perito Moreno Glacier - El Calafate

FullDescription.p: Lago Argentine, a lake we will skirt on our way to El Calafate, is so impossibly turquoise blue it looks like it has its own technicolor filter, but the secret behind the crazy hues of the water is the Perito Moreno glacier feeding the lake.
No trip to Patagonia would be complete without seeing the famous Perito Moreno glacier, a beast of an icefield towering 240 feet above the waters of Lago Argentino.

Glistening in the most incredible hues of blue and white, Perito Moreno glacier is a sight to behold: slowly advancing forward, this creaking, shuddering, breaking mass of ice looks like a frozen tsunami, and today, weâ€™ll get to see it from up close.

Itâ€™s a scenic ride to the viewpoint of the glacier with plenty of twisties and big, sweeping curves along the way. When we arrive, weâ€™ll leave the bikes at the parking lot and take a shuttle or do a short hike to admire the glacier from several different lookout points. Be sure to put on a warmer layer â€“ it gets chilly near the glacier!

After exploring the Perito Moreno area, weâ€™ll jump back on the bikes and return to El Calafate enjoying the breath-taking views of Lake Argentino. We recommend taking an hour or two to explore El Calafate on foot: itâ€™s the adventure capital of Argentinian Patagonia and itâ€™s worth checking out its quirky bohemian cafes, artisan shops, and local eateries.
Youâ€™ve already caught a glimpse of the Blue Towers, but today we will be riding right across the Torres del Paine National Park, one of the most stunning national parks in Patagonia.

Expect gale-force side winds, stark climates, and landscapes straight from Lord of the Rings. The towering Paine peaks, the wild, untamed land and the last 90km of gravel roads leading us deeper and deeper into the Patagonian backcountry, will leave you breathless.
Thereâ€™s no WiFi either tonight or tomorrow as we will be staying right here in the National Park territory.

Today we can explore Torres del Paine in more depth, riding the Park with a local guide. Itâ€˜s a seven-hour loop of the area, so if youâ€™d rather rest up please feel free. However, the riding, the scenery, and the feeling of complete, unbridled freedom as you discover Torres del Paine with locals is something we highly recommend.

Crossing the southern section of Torres del Paine National Park, weâ€™ll head South, traversing a wild, untouched country of gauchos and windswept roads, taking us to Punta Arenas, Chileâ€™s southernmost port city known for its Antarctic expeditions (and Chilean lamb asado, which is to die for by the way). 300km of pure two-wheeled bliss awaits, with gravel sections here and there, a lake inhabited by flamingos and a stop in Puerto Natales along the way thrown in for good measure.
This is the day youâ€™ll reach Fin del Mundo!

After a ferry crossing to Porvenir, weâ€™ll ride Tierra del Fuego, an island famous for its otherworldly scenery of Antarctic tundra, the stunning Garibaldi Pass and finally, Ushuaia, the Worldâ€™s southernmost city where the road literally ends.
Itâ€™s a long day with another border crossing â€“ Tierra del Fuego belongs to both Chile and Argentina â€“ but we promise the riding, the landscapes and the feeling of reaching Ushuaia will be the biggest reward yet.

Congratulations: you have reached the Worldâ€™s End! If youâ€™d like to celebrate with a hearty lunch and a glass of local Fernet, we donâ€™t blame you. If, however, youâ€™d rather take a ride for that iconic photo at the Fin del Mundo sign, see where Route 3 ends, or take a boat to the Beagle Channel, weâ€™re up for it!

Finishing this epic adventure with a bang: we have a long distance of 620km, but weâ€™ll travel nicely paved roads and the daylight in Patagonia is always on our side! Weâ€™ll cross the enchanting Tierra del Fuego, once more heading for another short ferry crossing, then loop back towards Punta Arenas for a celebratory farewell dinner on the Chilean side.

Itâ€™s hard to believe, but the journey ends here. Youâ€™ve traversed the length of Patagonia on your motorcycle, braved the mountains and the steppe, survived the notorious sidewinds, crossed Tierra del Fuego, and reached the Worldâ€™s End: an adventure of a lifetime indeed! We wish you a safe journey homeâ€¦ until the road calls again.
